medical_history.chief_complaint: The patient presents with complications related to Singleton-Merten dysplasia.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The patient's symptoms began at birth with intubation and resuscitation due to an Apgar score of 6 at 5 minutes. She experienced high blood pressure (104/70) and a significant heart murmur at 15 hours of age, leading to a diagnosis of congenital heart failure that worsened despite treatment. At 10 months, high blood pressure (130/85) and a puffy eye were noted. By three years, she exhibited developmental delays and bilateral genu valgus deformity. By 11 years, recurrent tonsillar attacks occurred, and at 12 years, she was admitted for high blood pressure (200/40) due to non-compliance with medications. Resistant hypertension remained unexplained at 13 years, and whole-exome sequencing at 16 years confirmed GACI type 1. At 17 years, she developed SLE with significant echocardiographic findings.
medical_history.past_medical_history: The patient has a history of hypertension, congenital heart failure, bilateral infantile polycystic kidney disease, rickets, dental issues, bilateral genu valgus deformity, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), and generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI) type 1.
medical_history.family_history: The mother had a miscarriage in the first pregnancy and a recent pregnancy with a fetus diagnosed with idiopathic arterial calcification that died in utero. Parents are first-degree cousins.
